title: Sterling Falls On Reports Boris Could Ignore No-Deal Bill; UK GDP Up Next
text:
Having spent a good portion of last week rallying in the face of Boris Johnson’s political problems, the weekend’s developments haven’t been greeted with as much glee by the .

Amber Rudd’s gone, with potentially more resignations to come, further weakening the Prime Minister’s hand. Monday should also be the day that sees the Benn ‘no-deal’ bill – which would likely require the government to ask for a Brexit extension – receive royal assent, snuck in just before Parliament is prorogued. In theory, then, there are a fair amount of positives for the pound to work with.

Instead sterling fell half a percent against both dollar and , tumbling to $1.224 and €1.1097 respectively – well off the lows struck on September 3rd, but nevertheless lacking the glint in its eye it displayed at its giddiest last week. That might be because Boris Johnson could well ignore any attempts to avert a no-deal Brexit by refusing to ask Brussels for a delay, something that would likely cause a legal challenge by the growing forces that oppose him. Such uncertainty is, of course, the pound’s kryptonite, hence explaining its early losses.

To add to its anxiety, the currency has to go through the data-wringer this morning. The monthly UK reading is expected to rise from 0.0% to an exhilarating 0.1%, while the and figures are both set to fall to -0.3%.

While the pound frets, the was able to fling itself back above 7300 with a 0.5% increase. That meant it outperformed its Eurozone peers; the added 0.3% as it nudged to a fresh 6-week peak, with the up just 0.1%.
